description: Borrowed from Middle French crudité, from Latin crūditās.

examples: What Art really reveals to us is Nature's lack of design, her curious crudities, her extraordinary monotony, her absolutely unfinished condition.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, medicine) Indigestion; undigested food in the stomach; badly-concocted humours.
examples: For there is no meat whatsoever, though otherwise wholesome and good, but if unseasonably taken, or immoderately used, more than the stomach can well bear, it will engender crudity and do much harm.
